results.title: First encounters
results.creator_credit: Ben Lewin, Karl McPhee, Malcolm Smith and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Migrant experience”.
Deals with the initial experience of various ethnic groups as they encounter Australia’s developing society and culture particularly the nature of the welcome experienced. Addresses what it is like to change cultural milieux, how forms of prejudice fit within Australian history and examines where attitudes towards migrants have changed.

results.title: Something to talk about = The Power of love
results.creator_credit: Lasse Hallstrom, Anthea Sylbert, Paula Weinstein and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: The marriage between Eddie and Grace (Julia Roberts and Dennis Quaid) is about to change big time when Grace catches her husband with another woman. Contrary to the belief that Grace is a meek, mild and passive wife, she does everything she can to draw attention to her cheating husband. Her actions aren’t appreciated by everyone however, including her father, a prominent figure in society who is embarrassed by his daughter’s public antics, as well as feeling threatened by her willingness to question masculine authority. Grace takes on the plight of cheated women en masse, and exposes the names of all the cheating husbands and their girlfriends in her Charity League meeting. Grace’s number one target however remains her husband, the only problem is her family keeps interfering which may help or hinder Grace’s plans for revenge, and change the family dynamics forever. Cast also includes Robert Duvall, Gena Rowlands and Kyra Sedgwick.

results.title: Setting out
results.creator_credit: Ben Lewin, Malcolm Smith and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Migrant experience”.
Surveys the chief events in Australian and world history that have influenced our migration patterns and immigration laws. Notes Aboriginal migration to Australia, the First Fleet, the discovery of gold, the land boom, drought and depression in the 1890s, Federation, World War I and after, the 1930s depression, post-war immigration, multiculturalism and Asian immigration. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: South Pacific
results.creator_credit: Joshua Logan, Buddy Adler, S P Enterprises and Magna Corporation
results.brief_description: Tender romance, an immortal score and enchanted South Seas splendour are set against the dark backdrop of a world at war, in this lush and passionate musical classic. The score is as breathtaking as the South Seas setting - “Some enchanted evening”, “Bali Hai”, “There is nothing like a dame”, “Younger than springtime”, and many more. Winner of the Pulitzer Prize, “South Pacific” ranks among the most celebrated of Rodgers and Hamerstein’s acclaimed musical masterpieces. Stars Mitzi Gaynor, Rossano Brazzi, John Kerr, Ray Walston, France Nuyen and Juanita Hall as Bloody Mary.

results.title: Something to hide
results.brief_description: Harry Field’s (Peter Finch) life is turned into a nightmare when he offers a hitch-hiker (Linda Hayden) a lift. His problems are exacerbated by marital problems and alcoholism. Also starring Shelley Winters, Colin Blakely, John Stride and Linda Hayden. Also known as “Shattered” and based on the book by Nicholas Monsarrat.

results.title: Are you fair dinkum?
results.creator_credit: Ben Lewin, Malcolm Smith and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “The Migrant experience”.
Looks at national identity and how the Australian way of life has been shaped by migration and the response of migrants to it. Shows the changes that have occurred as a result of the contributions of postwar migrants to Australian culture. Considers the role played by politics, the media and education.

results.title: Working
results.creator_credit: Karl McPhee, Malcolm Smith, Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “The Migrant experience”.
Considers the roles migrants have played in the Australian labour force. Several historical aspects are dealt with through case studies, though the emphasis is on the nature and effect of the postwar migration boom. With work as one of the most significant points of interation between migrants and hosts, this episode examines the experience of both good and bad of the new work force.

results.title: South Dakota "Dash for Cash"
results.brief_description: You’d be forgiven for mistaking this for a scene out of Squid Game, but unfortunately it’s not a hit dystopian TV show – it’s the Sioux Falls Stampede ice hockey team’s inaugural “Dash for Cash”, which saw local teachers compete for money to buy school supplies.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

You’d be forgiven for mistaking this for a scene out of Squid Game, but unfortunately it’s not a dystopian TV show where contestants risk their lives in murderous games for cash prizes – it’s the Sioux Falls Stampede ice hockey team’s inaugural “Dash for Cash”. The people scrambling for $5000 worth of one-dollar bills, while the stadium cheers, are local teachers, who intend to use the money for school supplies. After the footage went viral on social media, it started a seemingly much-needed debate about school funding in America, which saw many teachers reveal that they routinely used their own money to buy classroom necessities, as well as raised questions of how we ended up in a society where desperation is turned into spectacle.

The footage was seen as particularly callous towards South Dakota teachers, who according to CBS News, earn the lowest salary in their profession in America.

“While the Dash for the Cash may have been well-intentioned, it only underscores the fact that educators don’t have the resources necessary to meet the needs of their students,” Loren Paul, president of South Dakota’s teacher union, said in a statement to CBS MoneyWatch. “As a state, we shouldn’t be forcing teachers to wrestle with one another to get the money they need to fund their classrooms.”

At a time when inequality is growing globally and teachers have born the brunt of teaching remotely during the Covid-19 pandemic, more than a few users found the event tasteless at best and at worst, just another sign we’re living in the worst timeline. In response to the backlash, the Sioux Falls Stampede, and CU Mortgage Direct, who fronted the cash, released a statement apologising, saying: “we can see how it appears to be degrading and insulting towards the participating teachers and the teaching profession as a whole.”

The two organisations have since donated a further $15,000 USD to the participants.
description_for_label: You’d be forgiven for mistaking this for a scene out of Squid Game, but unfortunately it’s not a hit dystopian TV show – it’s the Sioux Falls Stampede ice hockey team’s inaugural “Dash for Cash”. The people scrambling for the one-dollar bills (there’s $5000 worth on the ice) while the stadium cheers them on are local teachers, who are going to use the money for school supplies. After the event went viral on social media, it started a debate about funding for schools in America, leading to an additional $500 USD being donated to participants by the event organisers.

results.title: South Africa belongs to us
results.creator_credit: Chris Austin, Westdeutscher Rundfunk and Gerhard Schmidt Produktion
results.brief_description: A film about black women in South Africa filmed secretly with the help of two black women journalists. Through interviews with five typical women, and comments from four women activists, including Winnie Mandela, the film clearly shows the devastating impact of apartheid on black women and their families. Narration by Peggy Phango.
